p:
As urban parks are open to the public, infected visitors can contribute to the expansion of several arboviruses. Furthermore, the continuous contact between humans, competent vectors and viruses make these parks high-risk areas for infection by DENV and other arboviruses, raising the question of the relevance of urban green areas in the transmission and maintenance dynamics of arboviruses
59– 61 . Bearing in mind the biological characteristics of Ae. albopictus, such as its vector competence for dengue, yellow fever, Zika and chikungunya viruses in laboratory conditions
46, 62– 64 , our findings reinforce the importance of surveillance and control of this species as it may be playing a role in maintaining circulation of DENV, favoring infection of those who live close to parks or visitors to these parks and expanding the distribution of the virus to other areas.
